column3: An $8 cap on late fees for credit cards, as proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, would lead to a substantial reduction in overall costs for consumers.
column4: Confidence in this topic (10 being the highest).
column5: Please explain your response in 280 characters or less.
column6: Requiring that all credit card fees and interest rates be transparent, prominently displayed, and easily searchable online would lead to a substantial reduction in overall costs for consumers.
column7: Confidence in this topic (10 being the highest).
column8: Please explain your response in 280 characters or less.
column9: Consumers would be measurably better off if efforts to reduce the impact of so-called ‘junk fees’ across the economy concentrated on making fees more transparent than on capping specific types of fees.
column10: Confidence in this topic (10 being the highest).
column11: Please explain your response in 280 characters or less.

column8: It is uncertain whether most customers would search, process and act on this type of information, given busy schedules, other transaction costs and sometimes low financial literacy.
column11: I am not convinced that transparency would work by itself. Capping fees could backfire, especially if these caps are excessively tight. But on balance, regulation may be better for ticketing consumers than just transparency. Still there is much uncertainty.

column5: This definitely reduce credit card fees. I also suspect this would it be harder for people with relatively low credit scores to get credit cards. In the worst case, more people low-credit borrowers will be forced to use payday lenders, which will be much more expensive
column8: This won't hurt. But I don't think it will have a substantial effect. People have self-control problems and succumb to myopic behavior in borrowing and repayment.
column11: I'm not sure that people respond strongly to this type of information. But I favor trying it. There's no good-for-consumer reasons that this information is made obscure. And the fact that is often hidden suggests that lenders believe that revealing it would save consumers money.

column5: The CARD Act evidence suggests fee caps may not be entirely be made up w other fees.

column8: Most of the costs are borne through the effect of merchant fees, especially interchange fees. Consumers bear these indirectly through merchant prices. Consumers will tend to pay more attention to the rewards funded by merchant fees. More competition might backfire. See Wang, 2023
column11: Consumers are not so attentive to banking markups. For example, they have trillions of dollars  of deposits on which the receive almost no interest.

column5: The Wall Street Journal, June 17, 2023, surveyed research showing that almost all casual thinking on this topic is quite wrong--transparency and the like steers people in just the wrong direction.
For most people, the benefits would be small.
column11: I doubt any regulator could find a good set of caps nor could one change the caps in response to new conditions. Transparency is better.

column5:
Credit card companies will adjust prices, products and availability to offset.  Overall costs (net of benefits) to consumers not likely decrease much. 
Possible for consumers to be worse off.
column8: Mixed evidence on effects of transparency to consumers in other arenas.
column11: Not sure what transparency does, but better than fixing prices / capping fees.  Generally not a good idea to fix prices / cap fees.
I don't know whether consumers are rational enough to do better with transparency than with a paternalistic cap.

column5: Some consumers will see reduced fees, but some others may be excluded from the market.
column11: The policies are complementary, and versions of both could be pursued.

column5: If the goal is to help relatively low income credit card users, who typically use basic cards,  it would be better to cap the interchange fees charged by the duopoly like it was done by the EU.
column11: Some fees are so egregious that consumers may not even search for them. At a minimum, forcing firms to display an all inclusive cost at the time of booking or  ordering, is necessary.

column5: "As much as $9 billion" in savings (per the CFPB) doesn't seem to me to pass the substantiality test in aggregate -- though it may be very important to some.
column8: Most consumers dont think these fees will matter to them and won't research them. Those who do get stung with late fees, on the other hand, are painfully aware of them.
column11: This is the standard economist's line, but I don't think it works well for fees that most people can rationally ignore because they are unlikely to pay them. (Does everyone on this panel know the late fees for all -- or even any -- of their cards?)

column5: Either fees will be shifted elsewhere or consumers who regularly incur late fees will lose access to credit.
Of course banks can increase other fees, but still the CFPB does seem to have shamed some large banks to eliminate these fees paid mostly by the poor.
column8: Don’t know whether enough consumers would shop for this to get up to “substantial” but worth doing.

column5: Perhaps in the short term, but I have little doubt in the capacity of credit card issuers to find innovative ways of hiding charges.
column8: Of course, the details matter. I worry that issuers might be similarly creative in circumventing transparency requirements. But a broad requirement of openness might be relatively easy to enforce.
